body: If you install with `pip install ipython[test]`, it should get the required packages for testing automatically. `mock` is declared as a dependency [here](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/5.1.0/setup.py#L213). `gnureadline` should not be a dependency at all for IPython 5.x; what failures are you seeing without that?

OK, should we update the installation instructions to suggest
'ipython[test]'?  They currently don't mention anything except `pip install
ipython` and then iptest fails.  Or maybe `ipython[all]`?

For the second part, about gnureadline, `iptest` complains:

Test group: utils
............................................../Users/gentry/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/utils/rlineimpl.py:61:
RuntimeWarning:

---

libedit detected - readline will not be well behaved, including but not
limited to:
- crashes on tab completion
- incorrect history navigation
- corrupting long-lines
- failure to wrap or indent lines properly
  It is highly recommended that you install gnureadline, which is installable
  with:
   pip install gnureadline
  ******************************************************************************
  RuntimeWarning)
  .................................S........SSS...S.....S..............S..S.......................................................
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Ran 174 tests in 1.677s

which complaint is obviated after a `pip install gnureadline`

Finally, `ipython[test]` doesn't seem to have a dependency on `matplotlib`
so some tests get skipped until you `pip install matplotlib`.

Here's a log that demonstrates all of these:

On Sat, Oct 8, 2016 at 1:55 PM, Thomas Kluyver notifications@github.com
wrote:

> If you install with pip install ipython[test], it should get the required
> packages for testing automatically. mock is declared as a dependency here
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/5.1.0/setup.py#L213. gnureadline
> should not be a dependency at all for IPython 5.x; what failures are you
> seeing without that?
>
